application_type_full: Tree works: Trees in conservation areas/subject to TPOs
description:
T1 (T1098 applicant reference number) Lime - Re-Pollard removing up to 3m
A1 (T2656) Sycamore - Crown Reduce removing up to 1m
A1 (T2654, T2655, T1104) 1xLime & 2x Sycamore - Crown Reduce removing up to 2m
A1 (T2658)- Sycamore - Fell
G1 (T1, T3) x2 Acacia - Fell
G1 (T5) 1x Acacia - Crown lift to approx 2.5m and reduce lateral branches to provide a 2m clearance to property

Located at TPO 199. 

The following works are protected by virtue of location within Hillingdon Village Conservation Area. 

G2643 - Mixed Group - Crown Lift to approx 5m. Cut back from streetlight to provide a 1m clearance.
T1085 - Cherry - Crown Lift to approx 5m
T1086 - Cherry - Crown Reduce removing up to 2m
T1087 - Cherry - Crown Lift to approx 5m - Cut back from streetlight to provide a 1m clearance
T1090 - Sorbus - Fell
T2645 - Sorbus - Fell
T2648 - Sycamore - Crown Lift to approx 5m
T2647 - Sycamore - Crown Lift to approx 5m
T2646 - Sycamore - Reduce lateral branches to provide a 2m clearance to property 
T2649 - Sycamore - Crown Reduce removing up to 1m
T2650 - Sycamore - Crown Reduce removing up to 2m
T1106 - Malus - Reduce lateral branches to provide a 1.5m clearance to property
T5 - Acacia - Crown lift to approx 2.5m Reduce lateral branches to provide a 2m clearance to property 
T1079 - Cherry - Crown lift to approx 2.5m Reduce lateral branches to provide a 1.5m clearance to property 
T1080 - Cherry - Crown lift to approx 2.5m Reduce lateral branches to provide a 1.5m clearance to property
T1081 - Cherry - Crown lift to approx 2.5m 
T1082 - Cherry - Crown lift to approx 2.5m Reduce lateral branches to provide a 1.5m clearance to property
decision_conditions: Timing of works:  Pruning works should not be carried out during the period of bud burst and care should be taken to ensure that branches are cut back to healthy outward facing buds to avoid die-back to which some species are prone. For major works, such as pollarding or copping, work should only be carried out after the autumn leaf fall when the sap has gone down, and certainly well before the sap rises in the spring before bud burst has taken place.

Wildlife and Countryside Act 1981:  Note that it is an offence under this act to disturb roosting bats, nesting birds or any other protected species.  Therefore, if applicable, it is advisable to consult your tree surgeon / consultant to agree an acceptable time for carrying out the approved works.

Works to trees protected by Conservation Area: The Council has not made a Tree Preservation Order to protect the other trees outlined in your application and therefore you can proceed with the work specified in your application / notice. Under Section 211 (3) (b) (ii) of the Act, the work must be completed before the expiry of two years from the date of your application, after which a further notice of intent to carry out the work will be required.

The re-growth / re-grown crown of the tree to be re-pollarded shall be removed. All pruning cuts shall be made above the previous pruning / pollard points in such a manner so as to minimise the impact to the tree(s) health and encourage the continued formation of a pollard head.

The works shall be carried out in accordance with the recommendations contained in BS3998: 2010 - "British Standard Recommendations for Tree Work". Climbing irons or 'spikes' shall not be used during the execution of this work.
In order to protect health of the tree and the visual amenity of the area.

The tree(s) to be pruned shall be crown reduced as per the approved specification. This work shall comprise a reduction in both height and spread over the whole crown by shortening or removing peripheral branches in a uniform and systematic manner.  Where branches are shortened, they should be cut back to a suitably positioned secondary branch.

Crown reduction shall not be construed as 'lopping' or 'topping' and shall result in a tree of typical form for the species and of balanced appearance. The works shall be carried out in accordance with the recommendations contained in BS 3998:2010 'Tree work - Recommendations'. Climbing irons or 'spikes' shall not be used during the execution of the work.
In order to protect health of the tree and the visual amenity of the area.
